awd_titl_txt: REU site: Advancing polymer materials by integrating chemistry and chemical engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This renewal Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Colorado School of Mines (CSM) offers unique interdisciplinary research experiences especially related to cutting edge technologies like fuel cells, solar materials, sustainability, and health care to highly qualified chemistry and chemical engineering students from diverse backgrounds. Polymer materials improve the daily lives of nearly every person in the United States. At the end of the 20th century, many mass-produced items, like car bumpers, started to be made with polymers due to combining good mechanical properties with being lightweight and cost effective. Technological innovation in the 21st century will also leverage polymer materials in the areas of renewable energy, sustainability, and medicine. Introducing undergraduate research experiences such as this will train our future human resources and help drive the plastic and polymer industry toward more advanced technology, innovative products, and efficient processes.

The REU Site offers opportunities for undergraduate students to engage in a 10-week summer research experience on cutting-edge projects integrating polymer science and engineering, using state-of-the-art methods, which reinforce and strengthen their classroom knowledge and encourage pursuit of graduate education. This will be achieved through integration of chemistry and chemical engineering. Unique aspects of this program include the exchanges between chemistry and chemical engineering students, as well as the range of application areas to be addressed - from renewable energy to sustainability to health care. Summer research activities are also supplemented with technical lectures as well as collaborations with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and the Children's Hospital Colorado. Another unique aspect of this program is the proposed workshop on the challenges inherent in commercializing new technologies, as innovations move from lab to market. This approach complements the strong professional development program that will prepare students to consider advanced studies in the field.

por.por_cntn:
Polymer materials improve the daily lives of nearly every person in the United States. At the end of the 20th century, many mass? produced items like car bumpers started to be made with polymers due to combining good mechanical properties with being lightweight and cost effective. Technological innovation in the 21st century will also leverage polymer materials in the areas of fuel cells, solar materials, and coatings. Despite recent economic problems, the polymer industry remains the 3rd largest manufacturing industry in the U.S. and is one of the fastest growing U.S. manufacturing sectors. In 2010, the U.S. polymer industry shipped $327 billion worth of goods, employed 910,000 workers in over 17,000 facilities, and maintained a presence in every state. These statistics demonstrate the importance of educating up? and? coming scientists and engineers in polymer science and engineering, which is the primary goal of our REU program.

Intellectual Merit:

Over the course of the REU site, we worked to improve and optimize all aspects of the REU site using REU student feedback and surveys, both during and after their time at CSM, and by holding review meetings with CSM faculty involved in supervising REU students, again both during and after the REU program. The salient findings of the past three years of this REU site are included here.

Each year of the REU site, the number of total applications and applications from women and minorities increased or remained constant, demonstrating the effectiveness of the recruitment strategies. In addition, for each year of the REU site the percentage of participants that were women or minorities was higher than the percentage of applicants that were women or minorities. Overall, the 49% of the participants in the REU site were women and 29% were from underrepresented groups.

Over the three years of the REU site, 32 total REU students were involved in research projects mentored by 16 different faculty members. In addition, 12 of the REU students were involved in projects that had a joint collaboration with NREL and 9 of the REU students were involved in projects that had a joint collaboration with CHC. Based on the exit surveys by the REU students, 95% of the total REU students responded that their research advisor ?cared a lot about my research project and me? and 90% of students responded that ?the goals of their research project were well defined? and rated their overall research project as excellent or very good. To provide the REU students exposure to research in the other discipline, each REU student spent eight hours shadowing work in the other discipline. The students unanimously stated that the exchanges expanded their knowledge and were a great way to learn more about a discipline different to theirs.

A series of workshops introduces the major topics in polymer science and engineering during the first one to two weeks of the REU. In addition, weekly lunchtime workshops on developing as a professional scientist or engineer were conducted for eight weeks of the program. From the surveys, 92% of the REU students stated that the technical workshops effectively prepared them for their research projects increased their knowledge in polymer science. All of the student participants stated that they learned a lot or some from the skills workshops that were offered during the REU program and that they had a better understanding of graduate school, obtaining an advanced degree and their interest in attending graduate school had stayed the same or increased.

Broader Impacts:

Each year of the REU program the REU students participated in white water rafting, hiking, attending a Colorado Rockies baseball game, and participation in Buffalo Bill Days, which is held in Golden. These events were sponsored by the host Departments at CSM and were completely free for the REU students. The overall social program provided during the REU site was rated great or good by all of the student participants and was outstanding in team bonding between the REU students.

As a result of the research that was conducted by the REU students during the three years of the REU site, 10 manuscripts have been published or submitted for peer review that include at least one REU students as a co-author. In addition, 7of the students who participated in the REU program presented their research as a poster at regional and national conferences.

By keeping track of all the students who attended the REU site over the past three years using our LinkedIn site, 100% of the REU students that could have obtained their degree in either chemical engineering or chemistry (based on their class standing at the time the attended the REU site) have obtained it. Of these students, 64% have entered graduate school, 31% have gone in to industry and 5% are attending medical school.
